text.body:
April 4th, 1916
Dear Marcelle:
I was mighty glad to get your letter but sorry to know you aren’t feeling exactly right. Those depressed feelings come to me too and I cannot find the source of them. I felt rather badly this morning too until I entered and found your letter and a letter from Betty’s mother telling me that her daughter had shown marked improvement.
They tell me I am to be sent to the reserve as soon as my perfectionment on the Nieuport is finished. I have done more than is called
[2]
for and am only waiting for Lieut. Chavane to return from permission before leaving for Plessis-Belleville. I believe I shall have to go directly thru [sic] but trust I can get a day or two in Paris afterwards. I certainly want to see you, Marcelle.
It seems queer being the first to leave over at the Nieuport place. I remember so well when I was on the Morane there and looked up to the Nieuport men. Then when on the Nieuport 23 meter I looked up to those on the 18 meter and the men that were leaving for Belleville I regarded as regular pilots. Now that I’m first in the school I don’t feel as if I knew [sic] much about flying. Thank
[3]
goodness I won’t have to be perfectioned at Belleville and wait around the way others have tho [sic] I believe that if I am given a 13 meter I’ll have to put in a certain number of hours on it.
It was nice of Mary Lines to write me in detail about Betty’s condition. Hope to see her in Paris and thank her personally. Speaking of Paris I feel a sort of shame at going there after the exhibition I gave the last time I was in the city.
Hope to see you in a few days.
Didn’t you get the photos I sent you?
Yours Jim.
[With this letter is an envelope addressed to Madmoiselle Marcelle Guerin, 148 Bis Rue de Longchamp, XVI, Paris.]
